timeline.bodyText:
Why these all variables are not final Strings/long/..?
Are they ever going to change?
timeline.author: michalxo

replies.bodyText: This is in public interface class and if you add final it's just redundant.
replies.author: im-konge

replies.bodyText: You cannot modify them, that's what interface do. You don't need to write final ... everywhere when you want a constants class -> so you do it this way. Is this right @Frawless?
replies.author: im-konge

replies.bodyText: Cool, I did not know that. Just googled it. Thanks! It's static and final by default.
replies.author: michalxo

replies.bodyText: It is because Java Interfaces are static classes and OFC cannot be instantiated. Static because at the runtime the value of the variable must be assigned in a context where instance does not exist. Final, because the value assigned to the interface variable is a constant that cannot be re-assigned by program code.
replies.author: see-quick

replies.bodyText: Thanks @see-quick, as always you described it better.
